section.title: Procedure
section.para: JGlideMon is distributed as a zip file named something like JGlideMon_core_vX.X.YYY.zip. X.X refers to the major version number. This number increases when there are signicant changes or additions to JGlideMon. YYY refers to the revision number. JGlideMon uses version control software called Subversion. This helps track changes and saves copies of older version of code in case something breaks and it needs to be reverted. The revision number is Subversion's internal version of JGlideMon. It increases whenever a change (large or small) is commited. It is possible that a version of JGlideMon will be released with the same major version number but different revision numbers. This would occur when a bug has been fixed or something minor has change.

After you have downloaded the core zip file, you must extract it to a folder. It does not matter where this folder is or what it is named but you should make it something meaningful, say C:\Program Files\JGlideMon.

For optional components, like text-to-speech, simply extract the zip file into the same folder that JGlideMon has been installed to. It is safe to overrite any files or folders if you are prompted to do so.

JGlideMon is also distributed as an installer file for Windows. Simply launch the installer and follow the wizard. If a version of JGlideMon is installed (that was previously installed with an installer) it will be upgraded to the new version. If Java is not installed, you will be prompted to download and install it.

In order to launch JGlideMon, simply double-click on JGlideMon.jar. For conveinance on Windows, you can right-click on JGlideMon.jar and click "Send To->Desktop (create shortcut)". If you prefer to start JGlideMon from the command line, you must invoke it like:
C:\> cd path\to\JGlideMon\Folder C:\path\to\JGlideMon\folder\> java -jar JGlideMon.jar

When you launch JGlideMon for the first time, you will be prompted to enter the network settings to connect to Glider. At this point you can configure other settings as you like. For further details, see the configuration chapter.
